awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Vision-guided Control of Robust Perching: From Biological to Robotic Flyers
awd_abstract_narration:
In a blink of our eyes, a fly can perch upside-down on a ceiling by executing a sequence of well-coordinated maneuvers triggered and controlled by a brain no bigger than a pinhead. This project aims to unravel how the robust intelligence of this process emerges from a synergistic combination of computational and mechanical processes, and how can they be translated to robotic flyers through an integrated biological and robotic investigation. Small robotic flyers suffer universally from high energy consumption and low aerodynamic efficiency. Robust perching will significantly extend small robotic flyer's functioning time and expand their applications such as environmental and disaster monitoring, aerial surveillance, and search and rescue. The project will also introduce biological and robotic locomotion principles to students and the public through visually appealing insect flights and robotic perching experiments, creating an ideal educational framework for STEM students of all ages. 

For small flyers, animals and robots alike, orchestrating a successful perching in dynamic and uncertain environments is one of the most challenging aerobatic feats. To land safely, a flyer has to solve a distance-velocity-attitude sensing and control problem with limited computational resources and under stringent time constraints. This project will first use targeted insect experiments with artificially-manipulated visual cues to reveal the computational processes that coordinate different maneuvers of perching in blue bottle flies, and how the computation takes into account dynamic physical environments and mechanical processes. Guided by the results from the biological perching, this project will accomplish robust robotic perching on stationary or moving surfaces using a centimeter-scale quadcopter. This will be achieved by developing computationally-efficient vision algorithms to extract essential visual information to control the robot's velocity and orientation prior to touchdown so that the robot can firmly attach to the desired surfaces with biomimetic compliant legs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we understood how flies land upside down on a ceiling in a split second.  This included the underlying biomechanics and vision-based control strategy. Successful inverted landings in flies involve a serial sequence of well-coordinated behavioral modules, consisting of an initial upward acceleration followed by rapid body rotation and leg extension, before terminating with a leg-assisted body swing pivoted around legs firmly attached to the ceiling.  We used the control strategy of the flies to inspire a robot control method that successfully flipped and landed small aerial robots rapidly on inverted surfaces, with the assist from reinforcement learning.  We systematically investigated how optimized inverted landing maneuvers depend on the initial approach velocities with varied magnitude and direction. Inverted landings were achieved in both simulation and experiments. The results of the robot landing will expand the possible applications of micro aerial vehicles, enabling them to perch on various surfaces, while saving or harvesting energy to significantly extend their functioning time.

This research generated new knowledge of the robust intelligence for small biological or robotic flyers to achieve landing with limited onboard sensing and control capacities. This research elucidated how the robustness of biological landing depends on the vision-based triggering, control and coordination of a sequence of behavioral modules used by files, and how their controlled leg movements provide mechanical intelligence to enhance robust performance, especially for more challenging landing such as those on inverted surfaces. Leveraging results from the biological perching, this research also laid out the foundation for robust perching of centimeter-scale robotic flyers by integrating computationally efficient and featureless algorithms (computational intelligence) with biomimetic compliant legs (mechanical intelligence). By examining the commonalities and differences between successful robotic perching and biological perching from scaling,aerodynamics, and computational perspectives, this research further advanced the knowledge on how does the robust perching emerge from a tradeoff between computational and mechanical intelligence.

This project has provided research opportunities for multiple graduate, undergraduate and high school students. The results, including the high speed landing videos from this project has been translated into graduate educational materials, and used by multiple agencies for making children educational videos and magazine articles .


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Bo Cheng
